title: Tech firms targeted in North East's active deals market
text:
Tech firms targeted in North East's active deals market 18:30, 14 Aug 2016 By chroniclelive.co.uk PwC's research shows there was a significant amount of private equity activity in the North East during the second quarter Shares   Paul Mankin, corporate finance partner at PwC in Newcastle 
In the first half of 2016 the overall M&A market was dominated by uncertainty and the impending EU referendum vote - but when it came to deal volumes, the North East seems to have bucked the national trend, as PAUL MANKIN, corporate partner at PwC explains. 
Globally Thomson Reuters recorded an annual 5% decrease in announced deal volumes to 21,087 for the first half of the year compared with the same period in 2015. The value of deals showed a 19% decrease over the same six month period last year and some of this decrease can be accounted for by fewer mega deals. 
According to Dealogic 59 such deals (US$10 bn +) were recorded during 2015 – 24 during the first half of 2015. 
However only 16 were recorded globally in the first six months of this year. 
Mergermarket recorded the lowest value of European deals since 2013 with values down 19.3% on the same period last year which once again can be explained by the decrease in number of megadeals as deal volumes increased by almost 20% to 3,110. 
The top targeted nation in Europe was the UK although activity dropped in the second quarter as the date of the referendum moved closer. 
A total of 647 deals targeting UK companies were announced during the first half of 2016, a drop of 8% on the same period the previous year but more significantly the value of announced deals decreased by 66% to £41.3bn. 
A similar pattern was recorded in the North East during the first six months in terms of deal values with the second quarter down almost 70% on the first three months although in reality this was accounted for by the £1.5bn sale of the Priory Group in February. 
Underlying disclosed deal values held up well with a total of £507m for the period April to June and interestingly deal volumes were up on the first quarter by more than 30% to 44. Compared to the first six months of 2015 overall deal activity in the region has increased. 
There was a significant amount of private equity activity in the North East during the second quarter with technology being a particularly active sector mirroring the global M&A picture. 
In June Middlesbrough based Onyx was acquired by Pulsant which provided an exit for Livingbridge who initially invested £16m in the IT infrastructure business in 2011. The private equity firm also exited Frank Recruitment Group during the quarter in a secondary buy-out to TPG. The majority stake valued Newcastle based Frank Recruitment at close to £200m. 
Performance Horizon Group completed a second round funding of over £10m in June which included new investment from the Greycroft Growth fund. The company, based at Boldon Business Park is a global leader in digital partner marketing. 
Private equity also invested in other sectors during the period. 
Synova Capital invested £25m in financial planning business Fairstone Group in April in order to grow the business through acquisitions. 
Also growing was Verdant Leisure who acquired two holiday parks in County Durham following a secondary buy-out by Palatine Private Equity. The £40m deal was an exit for RJD Partners who first invested in Verdant in September 2010 when it backed a management team in the buy-in of Dunham Leisure Limited. Cycling accessory distributor Zyro 
LDC backed the management buy-out of cycling accessories business Zyro who then combined with Fisher Outdoor Leisure Holdings to create a £70m turnover group. 
This increase in mid-market private equity activity was not only recorded in the North East. 
Nationally the Centre for Management Buyout Research (CMBOR) reported an increase in activity from 22 deals in the second half of 2015 to 25 for the first six months of this year. Total deal values were down but once again this represents a slowdown in the number of mega deals. Secondary buy-outs were also credited as a major source of deal flow. 
Of course most of the deals activity took place prior to the Brexit vote and we have yet to see the full impact on activity and values. 
What we do know is that we have been operating in a climate of uncertainty for some time and this looks set to continue. There is, however, potential for the short term impact to be somewhat offset by the significant weakening of the GBP versus the USD (at 10 year average lows), perhaps encouraging inbound activity.
